question: Before April 1, 2025, will Stripe announce that it is planning an IPO?
description: PaymentsDive: [Stripe shows signs of IPO, despite co-founder comments](https://www.paymentsdive.com/news/stripe-shows-signs-of-ipo-despite-co-founder-comments/727877/)
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**SGI서울보증 Announces Shareholder Reduction Policy and Investment Highlights**
SGI서울보증 held a press conference in Seoul on February 19 to announce its shareholder reduction policy and investment highlights, as well as its long-term growth strategy. According to Eun Myung-soon, CEO of SGI서울보증, 'Seoul Guarantee Insurance has played a role in activating credit transactions across the entire Korean industry for 56 years, and through this IPO, we aim to solidify our position as the country's only comprehensive guarantee insurance company and become a representative dividend-paying stock through more aggressive shareholder reduction policies.' SGI서울보증 plans to sell 6.982 million shares, or 10% of the total issued shares, to major shareholders, including the Deposit Insurance Corporation of Korea, which holds 93.85% of the company's shares. The expected price range for the IPO is 26,000-31,800 won per share, a 30% reduction from the previous IPO price band. The company has also established a new shareholder reduction policy, which includes paying a dividend of 200 billion won in 2024, which will be distributed to shareholders in April. This represents a dividend yield of 9-11% based on the expected IPO price range. The company has also set a goal of providing a total shareholder reduction of 200 billion won per year for the next three years. Additionally, SGI서울보증 plans to introduce a minimum dividend policy to increase the predictability of shareholder returns. The company will announce the specific amount of the minimum dividend in the first half of this year. The IPO is expected to take place on March 14, with subscription period from March 5-6.
Original language: ko
Publish date: February 19, 2025 06:49 AM
Source:[메트로신문](https://metroseoul.co.kr/article/20250219500513)

**New Paradigm Investment Announces 2024 Investment Results and 2025 Plans**
New Paradigm Investment announced its 2024 investment results and 2025 startup investment plans on February 19. In 2024, the company invested a total of 60 billion KRW in 14 startups, with 21 billion KRW in new investments and 39 billion KRW in follow-up investments. The company also established an 100 billion KRW venture investment fund for new and follow-up investments. New Paradigm Investment aims to achieve a follow-up investment of 900 billion KRW in 2025, a 12-fold increase from the previous three years. The company has already achieved a 703 billion KRW follow-up investment in 2024, with 395 billion KRW in follow-up investments from 14 companies, including Medical AI, which has grown significantly since its IPO in 2023. New Paradigm Investment has also achieved a 100% selection rate for TIPS-recommended companies in 2024, with a total of 34 companies selected so far. The company plans to continue investing in its portfolio companies and supporting their growth through value-up and scale-up. 'We aim to invest 80 billion KRW in 16 or more promising startups this year and achieve a follow-up investment of 900 billion KRW,' said Park Je-hyun, CEO of New Paradigm Investment. 'We also aim to nurture 20 or more unicorn companies by 2027.'
Original language: ko
Publish date: February 19, 2025 12:24 AM
Source:[mk.co.kr](https://www.mk.co.kr/news/it/11244437)

**VG ALERT: Kirby McInerney LLP Announces the Filing of a Securities Class Action on Behalf of Venture Global, Inc. Investors**
Kirby McInerney LLP has announced the filing of a securities class action lawsuit on behalf of investors who acquired Venture Global, Inc. common stock in connection with the company's January 2025 initial public offering (IPO). The lawsuit alleges that the defendants failed to disclose material issues, including delays in honoring supply contracts and lack of trust from a major customer, TotalEnergies. As a result, the price of Venture shares declined by $2.20 per share on February 6, 2025. Investors have until April 18, 2025, to apply to the Court to be appointed as lead plaintiff in the lawsuit. 'The complaint alleges that defendants, throughout the Class Period, failed to account for and address these issues which caused statements in Venture’s registration statements to be false and/or materially misleading at the time of the IPO,' according to the press release.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 11:00 PM
Source:[businesswire.com](https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20250218042303/en/VG-ALERT-Kirby-McInerney-LLP-Announces-the-Filing-of-a-Securities-Class-Action-on-Behalf-of-Venture-Global-Inc.-Investors)

**Tech Industry Layoffs, but AI Hiring Continues**
Despite the recent layoffs in the tech industry, some companies are still actively hiring in the AI field. For example, Workday is planning to hire 348 people, Meta is planning to hire in areas such as AI, infrastructure, and cloud computing, and Stripe is planning to increase its employee count by 17% by the end of 2025. Salesforce is also planning to hire 2000 sales representatives specializing in AI products. Microsoft has started layoffs based on performance, but is also hiring in areas such as security, experience, and gaming. 'We will continue to hire in important strategic areas and locations by 2026,' said Carl Eschenbach, CEO of Workday. 'We are prioritizing innovation investments in AI and platform development, and evaluating ROI strictly.' 'We will focus on hiring in areas such as infrastructure, revenue, Reality Labs, and AI,' said Meta in its fourth quarter earnings report. 'We will also accelerate hiring in machine learning engineering,' according to an internal memo. 'We will not slow down hiring,' said Rob McIntosh, CPO of Stripe. 'We plan to increase our employee count to around 10,000 by the end of 2025, which is a 17% increase from last year.'
Original language: ja
Publish date: February 18, 2025 10:34 PM
Source:[businessinsider.jp](https://www.businessinsider.jp/article/2502-tech-companies-hiring-job-openings-ai-cloud-infrastructure-layoffs-2025-2/)

**Forbes Reveals the 50 Most Promising Fintech Startups of 2025**
After a challenging 2023, the fintech industry showed signs of recovery in 2024. The valuations of some of the largest private fintech companies, such as Stripe and Ramp, increased, and the stocks of publicly traded companies, such as Affirm, Coinbase, and Robinhood, rose. However, global funding for private fintechs continued to decline, reaching $34 billion last year, compared to $42 billion in 2023 and a record $144 billion in 2021, according to CB Insights. Our new Fintech 50 list of 2025 is filled with entrepreneurs who have found ways to thrive in this limited and sometimes turbulent environment. Companies that provide services to other businesses (most of which are included in our Payment, Corporate Banking, and Wall Street and Companies categories) performed particularly well, taking 31 of the total 50 spots. These three categories also represent 13 of the 18 companies that made their debut in the Fintech 50 list this year. 'We analyzed hundreds of companies and evaluated everything from business growth and product innovation to leadership team diversity,' said our team of 10 journalists and editors. 'We interviewed both CEOs and industry experts. To be considered, emerging fintechs must have their headquarters or substantial operations in the US and not be part of a public company.' The companies that made it to the list were selected based on their growth, innovation, and leadership team diversity. 'We're seeing a lot of innovation in the fintech space, and it's exciting to see companies like Parafin and Squire making a big impact,' said Stacy Greiner, CEO of DailyPay. 'We're proud to be part of the Fintech 50 list and look forward to continuing to innovate and disrupt the financial services industry.' 
Original language: es
Publish date: February 18, 2025 05:53 PM
Source:[Forbes México](https://forbes.com.mx/estas-son-las-50-startups-fintech-mas-prometedoras-de-2025/)

**They've Been Waiting Years to Go Public. They're Still Waiting.**
Turo, a car rental start-up, has canceled its initial public offering (IPO) due to market uncertainty. The company's CEO, Andre Haddad, stated, 'Now is not the right time.' Despite President Trump's pro-business administration, the IPO market has been slow due to factors such as tariffs, regulatory changes, and inflation. According to Phil Haslett, a founder of EquityZen, the calendar for IPOs has gone from fully booked to wide open in three weeks. While some companies, like Klarna and eToro, have confidentially filed to list their shares, many valuable private tech companies, including Stripe and Databricks, plan to stay private by raising capital from the private market. David Solomon, CEO of Goldman Sachs, said that start-ups can get the capital they need from private investors, making it easier for them to stay private. The number and size of tender offerings have grown, allowing employees and shareholders to cash out and reducing the pressure to go public. Companies like Justworks and Navan have delayed or scrapped their IPO plans due to market volatility and poor performance of listed companies.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 02:51 PM
Source:[The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/18/technology/theyve-been-waiting-years-to-go-public-theyre-still-waiting.html)

**Circle IPO: How to Buy Circle Stock in 2025?**
Circle, a digital currency company, is not yet publicly traded, but it has filed for a US IPO in early 2024. The company's USD Coin (USDC) stablecoin has a market capitalization of $56.5 billion, making it the 7th largest cryptocurrency. Circle offers a range of products and services, including trading services through its platform, and has a focus on institutional clients through its Circle Invest services. According to valuations from previous funding rounds, Circle's potential IPO valuation could be in the range of $7-9 billion. A Circle representative noted, 'Becoming a U.S.-listed public company has long been part of Circle’s strategic aspirations,' but declined to comment on rumors. It is possible that Circle will go public sometime in 2025, and investors can gain indirect exposure to the company by investing in companies with an equity stake in it, such as Coinbase.

Publish date: February 18, 2025 01:15 PM
Source:[coincodex.com](https://coincodex.com/article/35620/circle-stock/)

**Shein Faces Pressure to Lower Valuation to $30 Billion Before London IPO**
Shein, a fast-fashion online retailer, is under pressure to lower its valuation to around $30 billion before its initial public offering (IPO) in London, according to Bloomberg News. Investors are suggesting that a reduction is needed to facilitate the possible IPO in the UK. A Shein spokesperson declined to comment. Shein aims to go public in London in the first half of this year. In early February, Reuters reported that Shein was planning to cut its valuation for the London IPO to around $50 billion, which is nearly a quarter less than the company's $66 billion fundraising value in 2023. Shein's IPO in London is subject to approval from UK and Chinese regulators. The Financial Times reported last week that Shein's IPO may be delayed until the second half of this year due to the decision by US President Donald Trump to end the duty-free importation 'de minimis' arrangement.

**From IPOs To Exits, Cross-Border Payments Is Set For An Active Year In The Markets**
The cross-border payments industry is expected to have an active year in 2025, with several companies planning to go public through IPOs or direct listings. However, the market conditions are different from 2021, when a flurry of cross-border payments players made their public entries. The financial landscape has changed, with enthusiasm for SPACs disappearing and concerns about turbulence and volatility due to provocative policies from the incoming US administration. Payments processor Stripe's valuation has dropped from $95bn in 2021 to $65bn in 2024, and investors will be looking to get the best possible return on their investment. Some companies, such as Ebury and Klarna, have already appointed banks to begin the IPO process, while others, like MoneyGram, have been exploring the option of being acquired by private equity players. The trend of market exits is also expected to continue, with several players considering or announcing deals with private equity players.

**Klarna scores global payment deal with Stripe to expand reach ahead of blockbuster U.S. IPO**
Klarna, a 'buy-now, pay-later' firm, has agreed to a major distribution partnership with Stripe to expand its reach and add more merchants ahead of its upcoming U.S. IPO. The partnership will make Klarna's BNPL service available as a payment option for merchants using Stripe's tools in 26 countries. This deal is a significant boost for Klarna, which aims to return to profit by summer 2023. According to David Sykes, Klarna's chief commercial officer, the company has already doubled the number of new merchants in the three months since implementing the new integration with Stripe. The deal also has the potential to drive incremental revenue gains for Stripe, which has seen BNPL volume grow 172% last year. As Jeanne Grosser, chief business officer of Stripe, said, 'This is a win-win for both firms.'

**Forecast: 13 Companies That Could Go Public In 2025 If The IPO Market Gains Steam**
Crunchbase News has identified 13 companies that could go public in 2025 if the IPO market gains steam. The list includes Cerebras Systems, CoreWeave, Snyk, SymphonyAI, Stripe, Klarna, Revolut, Hinge Health, Element Biosciences, Navan, StubHub, Discord, and Canva. These companies have shown significant growth and have the potential to meet the requirements for a successful IPO. Cerebras Systems, for example, has already filed to go public and is expected to do so soon. CoreWeave has raised $1.1 billion in funding and is valued at $19 billion. Snyk has grown its revenue by 50% and has cut its losses by 33%. SymphonyAI has hired a new CFO who has experience leading companies to IPOs. Stripe has made moves to signal its intention to go public, including hiring a new CFO and releasing an annual letter. Klarna has filed confidentially to go public and has reported revenue of $1.2 billion in H1 2024. Revolut has increased revenue to $2.2 billion and reported profits of $545 million. Hinge Health has hired investment bankers to lead an early-2025 IPO. Element Biosciences has raised $678 million in equity funding and is ripe for an offering. Navan has reportedly filed confidentially for an IPO and has hired a new CFO. StubHub has reportedly been contemplating an IPO for some time and has quietly hired a CFO. Discord has raised nearly $1 billion from private investors and has been working to diversify its revenue streams. Canva has hired a new CFO who helped take Zoom public and has raised a whopping $2.5 billion from investors.

**Regulation, deals and crypto: Fintech themes to watch in ’25**
The fintech industry is expected to see a positive turn in 2025, with interest-rate cuts, recoveries in fintech stocks, and a looser regulatory environment under the incoming Trump administration. After a challenging adjustment period following the Covid-19 pandemic, fintech startups are optimistic about new technologies like stablecoins and increased deal activity. According to Amias Gerety, partner at QED Investors, 'It will have an immediate impact on tone, and you’ll have a relatively swift change in terms of the experiments people are willing to do, the things they think about prioritizing.' The Ark Fintech Innovation ETF rose about 34% in 2024, and publicly traded fintech companies are expected to bounce back. Buy-now, pay-later firm Klarna and neobank Chime Financial Inc. have filed for initial public offerings, and Stripe Inc. and Plaid Inc. are other closely watched IPO contenders. Fintech venture funding has slowed to pre-pandemic levels, but investors are expecting to see similar deals take shape in 2025. The incoming administration's pro-crypto agenda is likely to put wind in the sails of efforts to utilize technologies like stablecoins, especially for those trying to expand internationally. Payment processor Stripe's $1.1 billion acquisition of stablecoin issuing startup Bridge was motivated by a desire to build global payments infrastructure.

**The Five Most Anticipated IPOs of 2025**
The IPO market is expected to pick up in 2025, with several companies already showing interest in going public. According to a report, the five most anticipated IPOs of 2025 are Chime, Stripe, Klarna, Databricks, and Stubhub. Chime, a fintech company, has filed confidential paperwork with the SEC and is expected to raise $22.7 billion. Stripe, a Dublin and San-Francisco-based fintech firm, has valued itself at $65 billion and has taken in $9 billion in venture funding since its founding in 2010. Klarna, a Swedish fintech company, has been streamlining its business with AI and has reported half-year revenue of $1.2 billion, an increase of 27 percent from a year ago. Databricks, a maker of cloud-based data analytics and AI products, has raised a whopping $10 billion in Series J funding and has a valuation of $62 billion. Stubhub, the ticketing giant, has been spooked by the iffy market but is poised to make a splashy IPO when the time is right. 'It's dumb to IPO this year,' said Databricks CEO Ali Ghodsi, citing regulatory and political uncertainty. 'The earliest theoretical possibility of an IPO would be next year, [2025] and then there's lock-up periods, so it would just be too long of a period for employees to get liquidity,' he added.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 26, 2024 02:30 PM
Source:[biztoc.com](https://www.inc.com/sam-blum/the-five-most-anticipated-ipos-of-2025/91067152?ref=biztoc.com)

**The IPO Comeback? What 2025 Could Hold For Fintechs Eyeing Public Markets**
The fintech sector may be gearing up for a resurgence in public markets in 2025, after years of turbulence. Companies like Chime Financial, Stripe, Klarna, and Circle are signaling a potential comeback in the IPO market. The sector faced significant headwinds in recent years, including overhyped valuations and shaky business models, but is now positioning itself to take advantage of improved conditions. Fintechs are refining their operations and ensuring stronger fundamentals and clearer paths to profitability before going public. The optimism around 2025 is warranted, but fintechs considering an IPO would do well to learn from the mistakes of their predecessors, such as Robinhood and Ant Group. Stripe's potential IPO could be the crown jewel of the 2025 fintech wave, and its success could set a positive tone for other fintechs. The IPO landscape isn't limited to the U.S., with regional fintechs in Southeast Asia and Europe also preparing for public listings.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 23, 2024 08:02 AM
Source:[Forbes](https://www.forbes.com/sites/zennonkapron/2024/12/23/the-ipo-comeback-what-2025-could-hold-for-fintechs-eyeing-public-markets/)

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, with many tech companies, the transition from private to public has followed industry trends and economic conditions. Based on data from similar tech firms, there's often a 25% likelihood in any given year for a well-known tech company at this stage to announce an IPO. This base rate comes from analyzing IPO announcements of companies valued over $1 billion within 3-5 years of reaching unicorn status.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Global economic conditions can significantly influence IPO decisions. If the Federal Reserve's current policies support a stable economic environment, especially with low interest rates that encourage investment, this could ease capital market conditions and facilitate IPOs.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Market Volatility
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Increased market volatility, driven by geopolitical tensions or economic factors, might deter companies from announcing IPOs as uncertainty in public markets can lower the valuation.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Financial Performance
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Stripe's financial health and performance, if reported as strong, can boost investor confidence and management's inclination to go public to leverage high valuations.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Multiple articles have cited Stripe as a strong contender for a 2025 IPO. The Motley Fool and Economic Times have both highlighted Stripe as one of the 'highly anticipated' IPOs for the year. Additionally, Stripe's integration with Klarna, aimed at expanding its reach, suggests strategic positioning consistent with preparations for a public offering.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The New York Times article indicates many tech companies, including Stripe, are choosing to stay private due to market uncertainties and can raise necessary capital from private markets.
